alert.note: Alert for Erie (New York) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued February 17 at 10:49PM EST until February 18 at 10:00AM EST by NWS Buffalo
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in New York... Cattaraugus Creek At Gowanda affecting Chautauqua, Erie, Cattaraugus and Wyoming Counties. Cazenovia Creek Near Ebenezer affecting Erie County. Cayuga Creek Near Lancaster affecting Wyoming and Erie Counties. Ellicott Creek Near Williamsville affecting Erie and Genesee Counties. Tonawanda Creek At Batavia affecting Wyoming, Erie, Niagara and Genesee Counties. .The following flood warnings are for high flows from rain and snowmelt. Potential ice jams through tonight may result in more significant flooding localized near ice jams. For the Cattaraugus Creek...including Gowanda...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Cazenovia Creek...including Ebenezer...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Cayuga Creek...including Lancaster...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Ellicott Creek...including Williamsville...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Tonawanda Creek...including Attica, Batavia, Rapids...Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL LATE TOMORROW MORNING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Cazenovia Creek Near Ebenezer. * WHEN...Until late tomorrow morning. * IMPACTS...At 10.0 feet, Flood stage, minor flooding can be expected in low lying areas east of Orchard Park Road and south of Ridge Road in West Seneca. Some inundation of Cazenovia Park in South Buffalo. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:00 PM EST Thursday the stage was 9.3 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage just after midnight tonight to a crest of 10.2 feet just after midnight tonight. It will then fall below flood stage late tonight. - Flood stage is 10.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 10.9 feet on 11/24/2014. - For more information please visit http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely. Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued Friday morning at 1000 AM EST.
